sections.motivation:
We investigate a problem at the confluence of two popular topics – graph
homomorphisms and signed graphs. Their interplay was first considered in an
unpublished manuscript of Guenin , and has since become an
established field of study . We now introduce the two topics separately. In the study of computational
aspects of graph homomorphisms, the central problem is one of existence –
does an input graph G𝐺G admit a homomorphism to a fixed target graph H𝐻H?
(The graphs considered here are undirected graphs with possible loops but no
parallel edges.)
This is known as the graph homomorphism problem. It was shown in 
that this problem is polynomial-time solvable when H𝐻H has a loop or is
bipartite, and is NP-complete otherwise. This is known as the dichotomy
of graph homomorphisms (see ). The core of a
graph H𝐻H is a subgraph of H𝐻H with the smallest number of vertices to which
H𝐻H admits a homomorphism; note that such a subgraph is unique up to
isomorphism. A graph with a loop has a vertex with a loop as its core, and
a (non-empty) bipartite graph has an edge as its core. Thus an equivalent way
of stating the graph dichotomy result is that the problem is polynomial-time
solvable when the core of H𝐻H has at most one edge, and is NP-complete
otherwise. Now suppose the input graph G𝐺G is
equipped with lists, L​(v)⊆V​(H),v∈V​(G),formulae-sequence𝐿𝑣𝑉𝐻𝑣𝑉𝐺L(v)\subseteq V(H),v\in V(G), and we ask if there is
a homomorphism f𝑓f of G𝐺G to H𝐻H such that each f​(v)∈L​(v)𝑓𝑣𝐿𝑣f(v)\in L(v). This is known
as the graph list homomorphism problem. This problem also has a dichotomy
of possible complexities  – it is polynomial-time solvable
when H𝐻H is a so-called bi-arc graph and is NP-complete otherwise. Bi-arc
graphs have turned out to be an interesting class of graphs; for instance,
when H𝐻H is a reflexive graph (each vertex has a loop), H𝐻H is a bi-arc graph
if and only if it is an interval graph . These kinds of complexity questions found their most general formulation in
the context of constraint satisfaction problems. The Feder-Vardi dichotomy
conjecture  claimed that every constraint satisfaction problem with
a fixed template H𝐻H is polynomial-time solvable or NP-complete. After a
quarter century of concerted effort by researchers in theoretical computer
science, universal algebra, logic, and graph theory, the conjecture was
proved in 2017, independently by Bulatov  and Zhuk .
This exciting development focused research attention on additional homomorphism
type dichotomies, including ones for signed graphs  [ref]8 . The study of signed graphs goes back to  , and has
been most notably investigated in     ,
from the point of view of colourings, matroids, or embeddings. Following
Guenin, homomorphisms of signed graphs have been pioneered in 
and .
The computational aspects of existence of homomorphisms
in signed graphs — given a fixed signed graph (H,π)𝐻𝜋(H,\pi), does an input signed
graph (G,σ)𝐺𝜎(G,\sigma) admit a homomorphism to (H,π)𝐻𝜋(H,\pi) — were studied
in  , and eventually a complete dichotomy classification was
obtained in [ref]8. It is surprisingly similar to the second way we
stated the graph dichotomy result above, see Theorem 5,
and the discussion following it. Although typically homomorphism problems tend to
be easier to classify with lists than without lists (lists allow for recursion
to subgraphs), the complexity of the list homomorphism problem for signed
graphs appears difficult to classify  [ref]8. If the analogy
to (unsigned) graphs holds again, then the tractable cases of the problem
should identify an interesting class of signed graphs, generalizing bi-arc
graphs. In this paper, we begin the exploration of this concept, focusing on
the case of signed trees. We find that there is interesting structure to the
tractable cases.
